importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The day before the IMO vote, President Trump made a public threat on Truth Social regarding the global carbon tax on shipping, directly influencing the decision to delay the adoption of the Net Zero Framework.
The final vote on postponing the Net Zero Framework was held on this date, marking a critical setback in global efforts to regulate shipping emissions.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Net Zero Framework aims to achieve a 20% reduction in shipping emissions by 2030 and net-zero emissions by 2050, setting a long-term climate target for the maritime industry.

keyTakeAways: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) delayed formal adoption of the Net Zero Framework (NZF) by at least 12 months due to pressure from U.S. President Donald Trump.
Trump threatened sanctions, visa restrictions, and port levies on countries supporting the framework, directly influencing the IMO's decision to postpone the vote.
The Net Zero Framework would have introduced a global carbon tax of $380 per metric tonne of CO2-equivalent emitted by ships.
The framework is intended to help the shipping industry reduce net emissions by 20% by 2030 and eliminate them entirely by 2050.
Despite the delay, 176 member countries of the IMO remain committed to climate action, with key supporters including China, the EU, Britain, and Brazil.
Opposition came from Russia and Saudi Arabia, while Argentina and Singapore, previously supportive, changed their stance after the threat.
The International Chamber of Shipping expressed concern over lack of clarity, stating that investment in decarbonization requires predictable policy.
Vanuatu’s climate minister called the delay 'unacceptable' given accelerating climate change impacts on shipping and ocean systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) postponed the formal adoption of its Net Zero Framework (NZF) by at least 12 months after U.S. President Donald Trump threatened sanctions and a global carbon tax on shipping emissions, citing opposition to what he called a 'Global Green New Scam Tax.' Despite earlier approval of the NZF in April, support from key nations like China, the EU, and the UK was weakened by geopolitical pressure. The framework, which would impose a $380 per metric tonne carbon tax on shipping emissions and reward emissions reductions, aims to cut net emissions by 20% by 2030 and achieve net-zero by 2050. Countries such as Russia, Saudi Arabia, Argentina, and Singapore shifted from support to opposition or delay. The decision has drawn criticism from climate advocates, including Vanuatu’s climate minister and UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres, who view it as a missed opportunity to advance climate action in the shipping sector. The International Chamber of Shipping stressed the need for clarity to enable investment in decarbonization technologies.
title: Trump torpedoes international deal to reduce shipping emissions
